commit_message:
Support filter backend based on operation type

This spec proposes to add attribute 'operation'
to RequestSpec when asking scheduler plugins
to perform filtering and weighing.

Partial-Implements: bp support-mark-pool-sold-out
Change-Id: I694ad2f8fab76b39ca1d9f4551102130faf5fc44
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/12/557112/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================== Mark backend pool sold out ========================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/support-mark-pool-sold-out This blueprint proposes to support mark the volume backend pool sold out for maintaining usage. Problem description =================== This is more related to administrative operation, when most of one specific pool's capacity has been consumed, administrator need the functionality to mark the backend pool sold out, that is to say, when the pool is marked sold out, it will become unavailable for **new users or customers**, but the pool's existing users still can perform any capacity consumed operations on their resources (volume, snapshot). Use Cases ========= Administrator can mark one of their backend pool sold out. Proposed change =============== Fully support marking backend pool sold out is a complicated feature as we have to consider several points: 1. Where to filter the sold out backend pools? 2. How can the administrators tell which backend pool is already sold out? 3. Where should we put the APIs to set, delete and show? 4. Where to store the flag that which backend pool is sold out? After the discussion during Rocky PTG, we decided achieve this by utilizing our current designs and codes, and that is, the OpenStack cloud vendors can write their own scheduler filter plugin. The new plugin is responsible for filtering out **the** backend pool as well as store the flags that whether the pool is sold out or not. Also the plugin needs to provide administrator a way to mark/unmark the backend pool. All of the changes needed in Cinder is to make scheduler plugins aware of action type when performing filtering for example, plugin can get request type via filter_properties as below: .. code-block:: python def backend_passes(self, backend_state, filter_properties): #get request type from filter_properties spec = filter_properties.get('request_spec', {}) request_type = spec.get('request_type', None) #perform filtering via backend state and request type return Based on our current features, the value of 'request_type' can be one of these below: 1. create_group 2. manage_existing 3. extend_volume 4. create_volume 5. create_snapshot 6. migrate_volume 7. retype_volume 8. manage_existing_snapshot Alternatives ------------ One of the alternative is to fully support this in cinder and in-tree plugins, but the biggest issue is the sold out strategy could be different among different OpenStack vendors, They may need different inputs or backend states. Only have request type supported in the framework means the vendors can quickly have their own plugins to achieve this rather than asking community to consider different cases in the **unified** sold out plugins. Data model impact ----------------- ``RequestSpec`` will be updated to store this new attribute. REST API impact --------------- None Cinder-client impact -------------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- Developers can develop new scheduler plugins based on backend state as well as request type. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: tommylikehu(tommylikehu@gmail.com) Work Items ---------- * Add ``request_type`` to those actions which will be scheduled to scheduler to perform filtering and weighing logic. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= * Add unit tests to cover this change. Documentation Impact ==================== * Update the developer document to mention the new attribute will be delivered to scheduler plugins as well. References ========== None

subject: Fix meter-label-rule creation
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-10-29 05:38:35.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/2dc869a6f71e1ef69355ba58d2cf8335d7cb8dd7', 'message': 'Fix meter-label-rule creation

The existing method is to meter outgoing traffic from the entire VM
to a specific "remote_ip_addr"(in case of outbound),
but the method I suggested can meter outgoing traffic
from a particular subnet to external network.

From a metering point of view,
it does not matter which address/CIDR is the destination for outbound.
But, it is important to know where(subnet or VM) the packet leaves from.
That way you can see how much VMs are using the external network.
For outbound metering, dst is 0.0.0.0/0 and src is network of VMs
and for inbound metering, src is 0.0.0.0/0 and dst is network of VMs.

When creating a meter-label-rule, it is correct
to specify src address for "remote_ip_prefix" option for outbound
and specify dst address for inbound.
If you are confused by the term "remote_ip_prefix",
you need to clarify this option.

Change-Id: Ia3f3e26410a73d7b44abae637703fda41c4bc09a
Closes-Bug: #1716913

commit_message:
Fix meter-label-rule creation

The existing method is to meter outgoing traffic from the entire VM
to a specific "remote_ip_addr"(in case of outbound),
but the method I suggested can meter outgoing traffic
from a particular subnet to external network.

From a metering point of view,
it does not matter which address/CIDR is the destination for outbound.
But, it is important to know where(subnet or VM) the packet leaves from.
That way you can see how much VMs are using the external network.
For outbound metering, dst is 0.0.0.0/0 and src is network of VMs
and for inbound metering, src is 0.0.0.0/0 and dst is network of VMs.

When creating a meter-label-rule, it is correct
to specify src address for "remote_ip_prefix" option for outbound
and specify dst address for inbound.
If you are confused by the term "remote_ip_prefix",
you need to clarify this option.

Change-Id: Ia3f3e26410a73d7b44abae637703fda41c4bc09a
Closes-Bug: #1716913
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/55/516055/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
